Description: Size of an individual cache block, representing a contiguous, naturally aligned power-of-two (or NAPOT) range of memory locations
Constraints: ['Must be a contiguous, naturally aligned power-of-two (Napot) range of memory locations.', 'Shall be uniform throughout the system (for the initial set of CMO extensions).']
Keywords: uniform, shall be uniform, implementation-specific, NAPOT, implementation-defined, power-of-two, shall

Description: Total capacity of a cache that stores data copies
Constraints: Implementation determines the capacity; no fixed value mandated

Description: Internal structure or arrangement of a cache (e.g., associativity, ways, sets)
Constraints: Implementation defines the organization; no uniform requirements
Keywords: implementation-specific, organization, organization of a cache

Description: Alignment requirement for cache block memory locations
Constraints: Must be naturally aligned to a power‑of‑two or NAPOT boundary

Description: Total capacity and structural organization of a cache (e.g., levels, associativity, number of sets)
Constraints: None explicitly stated beyond being implementation-specific

Description: Indicates that the size of a cache block shall be uniform throughout the system
Constraints: Must be uniform across the system

Description: Whether cache block size is uniform throughout the system
Constraints: Cache block size must be uniform

Description: The method provided by the execution environment for software to identify cache characteristics
Constraints: Must provide a means to discover information about caches and cache blocks

Description: Defines the total number of bits reserved for CSR addressing. The standard RISC-V ISA allocates 12 bits (csr[11:0]) for up to 4,096 CSRs.
Constraints: - Standard ISA uses 12-bit encoding (csr[11:0]), allowing up to 4,096 CSRs. - Could be extended or reduced by implementations (though not explicitly stated here).
Keywords: sets aside, 096 CSRs, may, up to, up to 4, implementation-defined, 12-bit encoding space

Description: The lowest privilege level required to access a specific CSR address as encoded in bits csr[9:8].
Constraints: Encoded in csr[9:8]; must correspond to standard privilege levels (e.g., U/S/M)
Keywords: encode, lowest privilege level that can access the CSR, convention

Description: Read and write accessibility of CSRs based on privilege level
Constraints: ['Top 2 bits (csr[11:10]) indicate read/write (00, 01, 10) or read-only (11)', 'Next 2 bits (csr[9:8]) encode the lowest privilege level that can access the CSR']
Keywords: accessibility, privilege level, conventional, by convention

Description: Convention for encoding CSR read/write accessibility and minimum privilege level in CSR address bits
Constraints: Uses upper 4 bits (csr[11:8]) of 12-bit CSR address; bits csr[11:10] indicate read/write (00,01,10) vs read-only (11); bits csr[9:8] encode minimum privilege level for access

Description: Encoding of CSR read/write accessibility and the lowest privilege level that can access a CSR using bits of the CSR address.
Constraints: - Uses the upper 4 bits of the CSR address (csr[11:8]). - The top two bits (csr[11:10]) indicate whether the CSR is read/write (00, 01, or 10) or read‑only (11). - The next two bits (csr[9:8]) encode the lowest privilege level that may access the CSR.
Keywords: read-only, upper, read/write, bits, encode, by convention

Description: Encoding of CSR read/write accessibility based on privilege level
Constraints: Uses csr[11:8] (4 bits); csr[11:10] indicates R/W vs R/O, csr[9:8] indicates minimum privilege level
Keywords: indicate, top two bits, according to privilege level, next two bits, by convention

Description: Whether a CSR is read-only or read/write
Constraints: Encoded in csr[11:10]; value 11 means read-only, other values (00, 01, 10) mean read/write

Description: Size of the encoding space for Control and Status Registers (CSRs)
Constraints: 12-bit encoding space, up to 4,096 CSRs

Description: Privilege levels that can access CSRs
Constraints: Lowest privilege level encoded in csr[9:8]

Description: Whether the implementation follows the standard convention for CSR read/write accessibility and privilege level encoding based on the upper 4 bits of the CSR address.
Constraints: The standard sets aside a 12-bit encoding space (csr[11:0]) for up to 4,096 CSRs.

Description: The accessibility of a CSR (read/write vs read-only) as determined by bits csr[11:10].
Constraints: Bits 11:10 indicate read/write if 00, 01, or 10; read-only if 11.

Description: The total number of CSRs that can be encoded.
Constraints: 12-bit encoding space, up to 4,096 CSRs

Description: How the upper 4 bits of the CSR address are used to encode read/write accessibility and privilege level.
Constraints: csr[11:8] used for accessibility and privilege level

Description: The bits indicating whether a CSR is read/write or read-only.
Constraints: csr[11:10] indicate read/write (00, 01, 10) or read-only (11)

Description: The bits encoding the lowest privilege level that can access a CSR.
Constraints: csr[9:8] encode lowest privilege level

Description: Controls the read/write (R/W) accessibility of Control and Status Registers (CSRs) based on privilege level (encoded in the upper 4 bits of the CSR address). The top two bits (csr[11:10]) determine if the register is read/write (00, 01, or 10) or read-only (11). The next two bits (csr[9:8]) specify the lowest privilege level that can access the CSR.
Constraints: - Encoded in csr[11:8] (upper 4 bits of the 12-bit CSR address space). - Must follow the privilege-level encoding scheme described in Table 1. - Read/write accessibility is conventional (not strictly defined by the ISA).
Keywords: privilege level, sets aside, may, encoding space, conventional, by convention, accessibility

Description: Specifies how privilege levels are encoded in the CSR address space (e.g., whether the encoding follows Table 1 or a custom convention).
Constraints: - Must align with the standard ISA's convention (Table 1) unless explicitly overridden. - The next two bits (csr[9:8]) encode the lowest privilege level for access. - The top two bits (csr[11:10]) determine read/write vs. read-only.
Keywords: by convention, encoding scheme, privilege level, as shown in Table 1

Description: Determines whether a CSR is read/write (R/W) or read-only, encoded in the top two bits (csr[11:10]).
Constraints: - Read/write: 00 or 01 or 10 (conventional). - Read-only: 11 (conventional). - Could vary if privilege-level encoding is non-standard.
